column2: Some Skink Priests are adept at communicating not just with other reptiles, but with all creatures of the jungle. They are skilled in manipulating the Wind of 'Ghur'.
The Spellsingers of Athel Loren shield themselves by joining their minds to the forest's sleeping consciousness.
Death whispers to the Bray-Shaman, who speaks the words to his enemies with hideous, incorporeal power.
Those with knowledge may summon great gusts of wind or fearsome arcs of lightning to harass their enemies.
This Plague Priest's one aim is to expend his life spreading deadly plagues to cripple the enemy; a power given to him through the Rite of the Pestilent Scheme.
The Spellsingers of Athel Loren shield themselves by joining their minds to the forest's sleeping consciousness.

Celestial Wizards spend most of their time gazing into the night skies, plotting the movements of the astral bodies. Their spells are able to call lightning from the skies and summon meteorites to smite the enemy.
Where there is dark there must be light. And so, just as day follows night, there are those in the Mortuary Cult who are skilled at banishment magic, and white wizardry.
The eldest of the fabled First Generation and the original Relic Priest, Kroak labours tirelessly to further the Great Plan.
Wielding powers seemingly tantamount to Necromancy, these dark Wizards can leech and hex the souls of their enemies.
The eldest of the fabled First Generation and the original Relic Priest, Kroak labours tirelessly to further the Great Plan.
It is no surprise that some Liche Priests excel at manipulating the Wind of Shyish, and are unsurpassed at Death Magic.
Some Skink Priests are adept at communicating not just with other reptiles, but with all creatures of the jungle. They are skilled in manipulating the Wind of 'Ghur'.
Although usually the domain of Clar Karond, there are Sorceresses who can wield the Wind of Ghur as well as any lash.
Not mere courtiers as the name suggests, but awe-inspiring warriors and envoys of the Everqueen, who speak with her authority in all matters.
Is there any greater dealer of death than a Sorceress at the height of her powers? Perhaps… but none will take as great a joy in unleashing it.

Devotees of the Lore of Beasts, Amber Wizards are renowned for their savage appearance; their hair is wild and unkempt and they dress in furs adorned with bones, feathers, amber beads and primitive talismans.
The holder of secrets and keeper of the way, whose strength is the quester's ultimate test.
The bravest of warriors, Paladins charge into battle either mounted or on foot, bringing righteous death in the Lady's name.
Spells cast with 'Dhar', or Dark Magic, are the most destructive. They are powered by the unrefined Winds of Magic, so the cost to both the spellcaster and their victims is great indeed.

While most Druchii Sorcerers use the dark in their magic, the fire from pyromancy is bright. However, those in Naggaroth that wield 'Aqshy' do not think of it as glowing flame, instead looking to the black, choking smoke that always accompanies fire.
Grey Wizards study spells of concealment and illusion, which do not lend themselves well to the favour of ordinary folk. They are sometimes called Trickster Wizards, though never to their faces.
As well as leading bands of Nagarythe’s most deadly killers, the Hand of the Shadow Crown excels at lone missions, be they sabotage or assassination.
Using his seer-craft, the Shaman-Sorcerer wrangles the Winds to guide the tribe towards war.

Skink Astromancers are relatively rare, their spawning marked with a meteor shower over Tlaxtlan. They serve the most powerful of their kind, known as 'the Beholder', who sends them far and wide in service of the Great Plan.
A Supreme Sorceress excels at not just Dark Magic, but also the ability to control and summon beasts - a true mistress of Ghur.
Balefiends revel in the instability they create between worlds, urging the Dark Gods to favour the Fimir once again.
This Necrotect's one aim is to spend his Unlife colonising a ruined settlement, a power given to him through the Rite of the Great Incantation of Ptra.

Bright Wizards are easily recognised for their red robes and wild orange hair and beards. They are of a fiery temperament, their anger changing from a guttering flame to a raging inferno in a split second.
Death stalks all that come to Ghrond, and those who wield the power of Shyish are more skilled than most in the murder's arcane arts.
Using his seer-craft, the Shaman-Sorcerer wrangles the Winds to guide the tribe towards war.
To control animals and twist their natural aggression to your own ends shows true mastery of your art.
Cloaked in the power of the beast, the Bray-Shaman uses his primal mutations to exert greater strength.

A Jade Wizard's power is linked to the seasons, being vigorous in spring, powerful in the summer, waning over the autumn and weakest in winter. They tend to roam the dark forests where Life Magic flows more freely.

Most Sorceresses of Ghrond lurk in the utter darkness, but there are those who still walk close to the light, using illusions to spin cruel visions and trick predators and prey, so they get the souls they desire.

Chaos Sorcerers who rip Chamon from the ever-flowing Winds of Magic use its flowing, glutinous form to shape metal into tools of dread, imprison souls in imperfect statues of gold, and to melt the armour from any who challenge their Ruinous Masters.
Proponents of the Lore of Life protect and heal friendly troops and allies, whilst forestalling their foes at every turn.
In the shadows of the great pyramids do the Liche Priests practice their dark arts. While some excel in Death Magic, or even Light, others have tamed Phantasmancy.
The Spellsingers of Athel Loren shield themselves by joining their minds to the forest's sleeping consciousness.
The earth speaks and the Bray-Shaman hears it. Nature flows through him, giving him mastery over the land itself.
Spells cast with 'Dhar', or Dark Magic, are the most destructive. They are powered by the unrefined Winds of Magic, so the cost to both the spellcaster and their victims is great indeed.

While most Druchii Sorcerers use the dark in their magic, the fire from pyromancy is bright. However, those in Naggaroth who wield 'Aqshy' do not think of it as glowing flame, instead looking to the black, choking smoke that always accompanies it.
High Elves were studying the night skies long before the astromancers of the Empire, and so can freely manipulate the Wind of Azyr.

This Warlock Engineer lives – and dies – to create or destroy, able to expend his life founding an Under-City beneath an enemy settlement, or cripple it in an insane Warpstone-fuelled detonation as empowered by the Rite of the Scheme of DOOOOM!
Balefiends revel in the instability they create between worlds, urging the Dark Gods to favour the Fimir once again.

A Chaos Sorcerer deals in death no matter which lore he wields, yet those who manipulate the Wind of Shyish take particular joy in ending the lives of mortals. It is their cruel laughter which is heard as the Purple Sun is summoned!
The Mages of Saphery excel at all forms of magic; the spells of shadows and illusion are no exception.

Most Sorceresses of Ghrond lurk in the utter darkness, but there are those that walk close to the light still, using illusions to spin cruel visions and trick predators and prey to get the souls they desire.
As master Phantasmancers, Chaos Sorcerers use the Lore of Shadows to confound, weaving an aura of darkness and dread about their victims.

Some creatures just want to see the world burn. The Sorcerers of Chaos certainly fall into that category, bending the flaming Wind of Aqshy to their ill wills, spreading fire and pain in the name of the Dark Gods.
Night Goblin Shamans wear the easily recognised hoods of their kind and are known for being particularly crazed due to eating vast quantities of hallucinogenic mushrooms.

While Elven Mages have the ability to use the combined might of High Magic, a few choose to specialise in certain areas if they have a gift or talent. Those that channel 'Hysh' excel at confronting and banishing Daemons.

Light Wizards are rarely seen without treasured tomes and arcane scrolls in hand. Light Magic is renowned for its powers of protection, yet a Light Wizard can also capture blazing lights to blind and burn a foe.
Shredded flaps of skin, clinging to a vicious humanoid wolf-thing, are all that remains of these former Champions.
Using his seer-craft, the Shaman-Sorcerer wrangles the Winds to guide the tribe towards war.
The Lore of Nehekhara was created by the Liche Priests of the Mortuary Cult in their quest to unlock the secrets of immortality.
Unlike men, the powerful Mages of Ulthuan can manipulate the full spectrum of the magical Winds and use a pure, combined form known as 'Qhaysh' or High Magic.
The realms of Ulthuan are filled with magical eddies that entwine and weave through the forests and heaths. Thus, there are Mages that master the Wind of 'Ghyran' like it was second nature.

Orc Shamans have been known to cause a foe's brains to burst out of his skull, shoot death beams out of their own beady eyes or summon an almighty green foot from the skies to stomp anything unfortunate enough to be underneath.

Skink Astromancers are relatively rare, their spawning marked with a meteor shower over Tlaxtlan. They serve the most powerful of their kind, known as 'the Beholder', who sends them far and wide in service of the Great Plan.
